definition: lit. chickens flying and dogs jumping (idiom)/fig. in chaos/in disarray
fowl/chicken/CL:隻|只[zhi1]/(slang) prostitute
to fly
dog/CL:隻|只[zhi1],條|条[tiao2]
to jump/to hop/to skip over/to bounce/to palpitate

sentences.english: You always leave everything off until the last minute.
sentences.chinese: 你老是拖到最後一刻才雞飛狗跳。

sentences.english: The assembly went out of control and became a scene of turmoil.
sentences.chinese: 場面失控了，變得雞飛狗跳，一片混亂。

sentences.english: The White House and the Pentagon would have barely stirred.
sentences.chinese: 白宮和五角大樓大概就不至於被攪得雞飛狗跳了。

definition: lit. not even the chickens and dogs are left undisturbed (idiom)/fig. great commotion/pandemonium
not recognizing one's family (idiom); self-centered and not making any allowances for the needs of one's relatives
to die without a burial site/to die a pauper/a tragic end
pinyin: si3 wu2 zang4 shen1 zhi1 di4

definition: proud and arrogant
overbearing/arrogant bully
lit. the river that divides Chu and Han/fig. a line that divides rival territories/the mid-line between sides on a Chinese chessboard
protective coloration/camouflage
clever and eloquent (idiom); fluent/having the gift of the gab
the shrike and the swallow fly in different directions (idiom)/(usually of a couple) to part from each other
to whisper to one another's ear
to take advantage of one's position to bully people (idiom)/to kick people around
to refute/to demolish (an argument, theory etc)
to bring trouble on oneself (idiom)
to behave unscrupulously
to withdraw/to hole up
annoying/disgusting
